item.title: Listening to Bach’s Fugues
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: The Well-Tempered Clavier, Book 1: Fugue No. 8 in D-Sharp Minor, BWV 853 I felt this fugue was…
item.content:encoded:
The Well-Tempered Clavier, Book 1: Fugue No. 8 in D-Sharp Minor, BWV 853

I felt this fugue was really lovely, especially because I enjoyed the theme and Bach used it frequently throughout this composition. In fact, I thought this fugue was quite theme-centric, with the theme inverted, augmented, and rhythmically varied. It’s also worth noting that this fugue goes from a straightforward exposition to a three-voiced narrative.

To be clear, some sources indicate that this fugue is in Eb minor; nevertheless, the prelude is in Eb minor, but the fugue is in D# minor in most scores I discovered. Although I don’t believe it matters, I’ll keep mentioning that this fugue is in D# minor.

This fugue begins with the first voice exposition of the theme, while the second voice (in red) imitate it. Right away, the lowest voice repeats it a second time. Bach repeats this three-bar theme four times in the first 14 bars, which shows how important this theme is to him.

In order to emphasize the theme-centric nature of the fugue, the theme is repeated five times from bar 19 to bar 29, before there is an inversion (in blue). I was interested to see if the inversion is an exact mirror of the theme. I got my answer right away: no. The very first note, D#, goes to an A#, the perfect fifth. However, the inversion goes down a perfect fourth. Following these first notes, everything is mirrored.

Afterwards, the lower voice plays an augmentation of the theme (in green) at double speed. In my opinion, this is where the piece begins to climax and become more complex.

It is difficult for me to follow and analyze without assistance from here. I noticed that the theme is imitated and reversed as well as amplified and augmented throughout the entire piece, making it a complex and engaging ending.

The Well-Tempered Clavier, Book I: Fugue No. 14 in F-sharp minor, BWV 859

I found this fugue to be slow, sorrowful, but at the same time, I found it to sometimes be beautifully harmonious. Contrary to other fugues I have heard, I believe this could be played in a church, with the long notes resonating in the long walls. Alternatively, a choral group could perform it.

The theme (in red) and countertheme (in brown) are presented in the first six bars of this fugue, which is interesting. The theme’s long notes are precisely counterbalanced by the countertheme’s quavers, allowing both to be heard clearly. When the third voice is added in the lower bass, it sounds really lovely to me. This produces a really fascinating and recognizable sound that binds all of the voices together.

I was curious as to how Bach composed the theme and counter-theme to work together so beautifully, so I decided to investigate further. One thing I observed is that both melodies, especially the countertheme, move in a step-by-step manner, only leaping in the finish. This, I believe, allows the intervals to move from fifths to thirds, as seen at the start of bar 5. In addition, the opposing motion in the first two bars, when one of the melodies rises (in red) and the other falls (in blue), generates a lovely contrast and tension, which is released in the last two bars, when both move in the same direction.

When I previously stated that I considered this piece to be quite harmonic at moments, I was making reference to bars 13 and 14. All melodies, I suppose, have the same function here: to set the stage for the return of the theme and countertheme, but this time in a more powerful form. The theme is mostly played by the two upper voices with the thirds. This brings the piece to a close with a mini-climax.

Something new appears later, at the conclusion of bar 20. The motif has been inverted (in blue). This inversion is accompanied by lower voice quavers that sound like the countertheme. I believe this is employed to have a familiar sound with this new inversion theme.

One last thing I’d like to mention is something I don’t recall hearing in previous fugues. When two voices play similar melodies while the other two wait their time to play identical tunes. As with prior examples, most of this is done using the third interval. All of this builds up to the final theme and countertheme section.

item.title: Listening to Stravinsky – Rite Of Spring
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: Bassoons are turning into one of my favourite instruments because of their sound and versatility of being able…
item.content:encoded:
Bassoons are turning into one of my favourite instruments because of their sound and versatility of being able to be both a rhythmic and melodic instrument. As I was researching about it, I came across the introduction to Stravinsky’s Rite Of Spring, where the bassoon plays an extremely unusual high note and a beautiful melody. As a result of this unusual sound, I was drawn to listen to the whole piece more closely.

Rite Of Spring was commissioned by Serge Diaghilev, the noted impresario of the Ballets Russes who had also produced The Firebird (1910) and Petrushka (1911) and it was not a huge hit on opening night (Schwarm, n.d.).

In 1913, the Rite Of Spring was received by the audience at the premiere at the Théâtre des Champs-Elysées in Paris with shouts and yells. There was so much noise that the dancers were unable to hear the orchestra. It was a total disaster (Stravinsky’s The Rite of Spring: Keeping Score | PBS, 2022). However, later became known as one of the most influential pieces of music of the 20th century.

This piece was influenced by Russian culture and folk-inspired forms and melodies, but its chaotic percussive momentum challenged its audience. Stravinsky, for example, borrowed the bassoon introduction from a Lithuanian folk song titled “Tu, manu seserėlė”. But he added multiple instruments and heightened this melody with dissonant melodies, recurrent changes in meter and rhythmic syncopations.

I can imagine the audience at the premiere of the Rite Of Spring being stunned by the orchestra’s clash of sounds. After listening to it for the first time, I got shocked when The Augurs of Spring, Dances of the Young Girls began. This work had so much power, violence, and changing rhythms that I was not prepared for it.

This piece relies heavily on rhythm as it leads almost all the parts. Even though the orchestral size of The Rite Of Spring is enormous, sometimes the rhythm is not played by percussion instruments but by other instruments, especially strings. In the Sacrificial Dance as well as The Dance of Young Girls, the orchestra’s percussive nature can be heard.

The rhythm sometimes evokes an African/Oceanic sound, as at the start of the Ritual of Abduction. Don’t forget that this piece was written at the height of African and Oceanian colonization. During the colonial period, there was a cultural clash that caused some artists to create art that didn’t resonate with previous creations. In a previous post, I discussed the importance of polyphony in Polynesia, which had a large French population. I wonder how much this influenced Stravinsky in the Rite Of Spring.

Creatively speaking, the piece possesses a lot of originality. Stravinsky layers a variety of melodies and rhythms on top of each other, creating what some would call noise. Yet ultimately, I believe this is a sonorous experience that requires dozens of listens to understand how each instrument fits into the music.

As I listened to the entire piece, I found it to be more enjoyable than I initially expected. What I enjoyed more than the rhythmic asymmetries, the dissonances, and the layers of ostinatos played simultaneously was the surprise element. Stravinsky played with the listener’s expectations and never let the music settle in a safe place, even though there are repetitions (especially underlying chords). After the listener becomes comfortable with a sonority, there is a twist, just like a plot twist in a narrative, and everything is new again.

As a result of this unexpected element, I understand why the audience at the premiere was shocked and furious. Apparently, it was the surprise, and I believe it was a loud one, that drove people crazy, even leading to the conductor, Pierre Monteux, admitting that “everything available was tossed in our direction” (Jones, n.d.). But this led me to raise a question.

Since when has music not shocked people? Almost since I was born, I recall tv shows, movies, and exhibitions that shocked the public. Music, however, does not seem to have shocked audiences as much. Does this mean that music is becoming less experimental? Is it because the audience is just accustomed to ignoring things they don’t like? Perhaps the “Next” button on the music player is to blame. Nowadays, listeners are not “obligated” to sit in a theatre for 90 minutes to hear a piece they’ve never heard before. What will be the next musical rage?

References

Schwarm, B., n.d. The Rite of Spring | History, Composer, & Facts. [online] Encyclopedia Britannica. Available at: <https://www.britannica.com/topic/The-Rite-of-Spring> [Accessed 11 November 2021].

Pbs.org. n.d. Stravinsky’s The Rite of Spring: Keeping Score | PBS. [online] Available at: <https://www.pbs.org/keepingscore/stravinsky-rite-of-spring.html> [Accessed 11 November 2021].

item.title: Listening to Scott Joplin – Maple Leaf Rag
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: Scott Joplin was a remarkable composer who was able to combine African musical influences with classical music from…
item.content:encoded:
Key takeaways

  • Scott Joplin was a remarkable composer who was able to combine African musical influences with classical music from Europe.
  • Syncopation adds variety and forward movement to music, making it feel faster even when the tempos aren’t.
  • The I-V progression is useful for conveying comfort and familiarity.

When researching for black composers I came across Scott Joplin, whom, I must admit, I didn’t know much of his work. Although I had heard some ragtime music before, I was far from knowing what exactly makes a ragtime song and how important it was to modern popular music.

Joplin’s History

Scott Joplin was born in northeastern Texas in 1867 or 1868, one of the first generation of African Americans born after slavery was abolished. His father used to be a slave, but his mother was born free. Both of Scott’s parents were performers, and he and his siblings grew up surrounded by music, primarily African traditional music performed by slaves.

Scott’s mother recognized his interest in music and was able to find him a free music teacher in exchange for housework. Julius Weiss, a German immigrant who, according to other students, was a follower of the European musical heritage with a special fondness for opera, was his teacher. Scott Joplin’s music owed a great deal to this. A descendant of an African slaver was not supposed to get a formal education, much less musical education. However, it was because of Weiss that he was able to understand piano technique, music theory, and, most crucially, European musical knowledge such as opera (Berlin, nd.).

The role of Joplin in Rag music

There is no doubt that Scott Joplin’s music took on the fresh feel it had because of the convergence of African and European music. He combined the syncopation of Afro-American folk music with the harmonization and marching tempos of 19th-century European romanticism to form the ultimate combination (Jasen & Tichenor, 1989). As a result, this led him to ragtime.

According to Grove Music Online, ragtime is “a style of popular music that flourished from the mid-1890s to 1918. Its main identifying trait is its ragged—i.e., syncopated—rhythm” (Berlin, 2013).

Joplin was known for his rags, particularly Maple Leaf Rag. Although it was not the first rag to be published, it was one of the most influential compositions in establishing ragtime as the first African-American music style to be widely adopted, earning him the title of King of Ragtime.

The Maple Leaf Rag and many other Joplin’s rags are considered Classic Rags. By “classic” we consider that the rag has a structure that “has three or four sections, each featuring a different 16-measure musical theme, or melody. In turn, these equal sections are divided into four lines of four measures each. Once a theme is played through, it is generally repeated immediately; in certain cases, it reappears later in the piece.” (The Library of Congress, Classic Rag).

Maple Leaf Rag is a good example of a Classic Rag since it not only follows the usual AABBACCDD pattern, is in duple meter, and has significant syncopation in the melody, but it is also very well thought out. To perform this composition successfully, you’ll need a developed pianistic talent.

Scott’s publisher, John Stark, believed his publications were as good as best classical music, and he promoted his view in elaborate ads. “Why are the Stark Music Co’s Rags called Classic? This is the reason: They are intellectual musical thoughts grounded in the emotional principle of humanity.” (The Library of Congress, Classic Rag).

My listening of Maple Leaf Rag

This composition drew my attention since Joplin defines the rhythm, speed, and atmosphere of the music from the first bar. He doesn’t build up any anticipation, and there aren’t many opportunities for both hands to rest. After playing this rag, I can image a pianist becoming really fatigued.

However, I believe that the absence of build-up, along with the melody’s powerful syncopation, results in a danceable and incredibly catchy music. At the same time, for individuals who are used to classical music and marches, the continuous simple bass progression (which is usually an I-V progression) provides a very familiar and comforting feel.

Philosophically, I believe the contrast between the syncopated melody and the structured bass reflects Joplin’s position in the artistic culture of the period. On the one hand, having been raised in an African musical background, he came from a culture where syncopated percussion beats are very prominent and where rhythm is vital to making people dance and interact with music. On the other hand, he was given formal classical training that allowed him to learn how the best European classical composers composed their works. The Maple Leaf Rag and others demonstrate that he learned from both cultures and passed them on to the composition.

You can clearly hear the syncopation and the I-V progression in Maple Leaf Rag’s first bars in the A section, where the bass line plays a steady rhythm, while the melody plays a syncopated rhythm. The syncopation is prominent in the song throughout.

Another key point to note is that, like previous classical composers, Joplin knew how to generate tension and release it. My past hearing of folk African music led me to believe that it was heavily reliant on repetition rather than dramatic moments. In bars 7-9, you can sense the tension building up.

In the B section, Joplin inserts chromatism to give the music a fresh perspective and, in my opinion, to instill the composition with some of his musical understanding.

The modulation from Ab Major to Db Major at the beginning of the C section and back to Ab at the beginning of the D section, especially the last one, is done quite smoothly. Although the modulation to the subdominant is a common ragtime modulation, I feel Joplin handled it in a fluid manner to once again demonstrate his abilities.

Another aspect of this music that I found intriguing is the triumphal finale, which has a counter motion between the voices and a large chord that eventually allows the pianist to rest after demonstrating his abilities.

Upon hearing Scott Joplin and reading about him, I concluded that he always fought for recognition. Despite the fact that Rags were not considered high-quality music, he had a formal musical education. I believe that confrontation is what caused his pieces to be considered so well-written, timeless, and a template for other styles that grew from it, including jazz.

After having studied both Joseph Bologne and Scott Joplin I find their similarities and differences very insightful. Both came from one musical background and were later exposed to another. But it did not impact them in the same way. The novelty and merge of cultures I was expecting, was more evident in Joplin’s music. My point is not that one is better or more relevant than the other. The two composers were inspirations and essential to composers who came after them. But when you think of music as an evolving landscape of different artistic viewpoints, I believe Joplin played a significant role in showing composers that you could mix them all and create beautiful pieces of music.

References

Berlin, E.A., Scott Joplin: Brief Biographical Sketch. Edward A. Berlin. Available at: https://www.edwardaberlin.com/scott_joplin__brief_biographical_sketch___33423.htm [Accessed November 3, 2021].

Jasen, D.A. & Tichenor, T.J., 1989. Rags and Ragtime: A musical history, New York: Dover.

Berlin, E.A., 2013. Ragtime. Grove Music Online. Available at: https://www-oxfordmusiconline-com.ucreative.idm.oclc.org/grovemusic/view/10.1093/gmo/9781561592630.001.0001/omo-9781561592630-e-1002252241. [Accessed November 3, 2021].

The Library of Congress, Classic Rag. The Library of Congress. Available at: https://www.loc.gov/item/ihas.200035813/ [Accessed November 4, 2021].

item.title: Listening to Joseph Bologne, Chevalier de Saint-Georges – Violin Concerto No. 9 in G Major, Op. 8
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: There are black composers who don’t get the attention they deserve, and Joseph Bologne is one of them…
item.content:encoded:
Key takeaways

  • There are black composers who don’t get the attention they deserve, and Joseph Bologne is one of them
  • I couldn’t fiind an African inspired sound in his works, maybe because of his European education
  • I find descending notes pleasing, once again

One thought occurred to me while I was searching for music to listen to. What is the reason for the scarcity of well-known African classical composers? I couldn’t think of one, and a quick Google search reveals that the first dozen names that come up are all white men. I recognize that my lack of knowledge stems primarily from my western culture, so I set out to find black composers, which I am glad I did.

One of the articles I read was from classicfm.com entitled “9 Black composers who changed the course of classical music history”. The first featured composer is Joseph Bologne, Chevalier de Saint-Georges.

Joseph Bologne was born to a wealthy plantation owner and his Senegalese slave mistress in Basse-Terre, Guadaloupe, in 1745. He received the best education his father could afford during the family’s move to France and grew into an exceptionally gifted student. He had professional training, as evidenced by his extensive work list, which includes a number of comedic operas, symphonies and concertos, as well as chamber works (Banat, 2001).

Despite his pejorative nickname of The Black Mozart (also known as The Other Mozart), I find myself wondering if it shouldn’t be the other way around. Joseph Bologne is regarded as one of the greatest composers of the 18th century, according to Marlon Daniel. He was known to frequent salons as a guest of the French nobility, including those of queen Marie Antoinette, who was an accomplished singer herself. He influenced Franz Joseph Haydn, François-Joseph Gossec, Carl Stamitz, and, most notably, Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, making him a leader rather than a follower of trends in the musical evolution of his century (Daniel, 2021).

His work was innovative since his earlier compositions, according to a New York Times article. “The six-string quartets of his Opus 1 were among the first in that genre to be written in France. His three sonatas for keyboard and violin (Op. 1a) feature those instruments as equals, breaking away from the Baroque tradition of basso continuo, which was still very much in vogue” (Balter, 2020).

Despite how innovative Bologne’s work may have sounded after listening to his violin concertos, my mind constantly tells me that he sounds a lot like some of his contemporaries. This, I believe, is a case of knowledge bias.

His Violin Concerto No. 9 in G Major, Op. 8 is one of my favourite works. I was struck by the three movements’ energy and rhythm, as well as the motifs he created. I couldn’t find a free score for this piece, but they can easily compete with other well-known motifs, in my humble and naive opinion. Why hasn’t his music been used in an advertisement commercial?

The second movement, Largo, is one of my favourites. Despite the fact that it is a slower movement, I consider it to be a continuation of the first movement’s accentuated rhythm. The syncopation provides a solid sound of descending notes in the first minute, which I find pleasing. In fact, I find this movement to be quite contemporary. While listening to him, I noticed parallels with Nicolas Britell’s, in my opinion, amazing Succession Tv Show soundtrack, particularly the Adagio in C Minor I show below.

In the end, I was thrilled about this discovery. I’m not qualified to say whether Joseph Bologne was a better composer than Mozart, but after hearing some of his works, I believe he deserves at least more credit.

References

Banat, G., 2001. Saint-Georges [Saint-George], Joseph Bologne, Chevalier de.. [online] Oxford University Press. Available at: https://www-oxfordmusiconline-com.ucreative.idm.oclc.org/grovemusic/view/10.1093/gmo/9781561592630.001.0001/omo-9781561592630-e-0000024316 [Accessed 27 October 2021].

Daniel, M., 2021. THE MUSIC OF JOSEPH BOLOGNE CHEVALIER DE SAINT-GEORGES. [ebook] Tafelmusik. Available at: https://www.tafelmusik.org/downloads/Tafelmedia/joseph-bologne-digital-booklet.pdf [Accessed 27 October 2021].

Balter, M., 2020. His Name Is Joseph Boulogne, Not ‘Black Mozart’. [online] Nytimes.com. Available at: https://www.nytimes.com/2020/07/22/arts/music/black-mozart-joseph-boulogne.html [Accessed 27 October 2021].

item.title: Listening to Beach Boys – God Only Knows
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: Despite not being a huge fan of the Beach Boys, I’ve always enjoyed this song, mostly because it…
item.content:encoded:
Despite not being a huge fan of the Beach Boys, I’ve always enjoyed this song, mostly because it doesn’t seem like a typical love song. But I’ve never given any thought to how this song’s melody and harmony were created.

I chose to explore this piece after reading this quote when researching Bach’s fugues.

God Only Knows is regarded as one of The Beach Boys’ best songs and is adored by many musicians, including Paul McCartney who admitted this is one of his favourite songs. (Paul McCartney Comments, n.d.) Brian Wilson and Tony Asher wrote it for the Pet Sounds album with the goal of moving The Beach Boys away from a mainstream boyband sound and musically challenging the Beatles (Whatley, 2021). Paul McCartney later admitted that God Only Knows and the Pet Sounds inspired Sgt. Pepper’s Lonely Hearts Club Band. So this creative battle was won by all of us.

I believe the song’s theme is about the end of a relationship and the doubts that follow it. The hesitation in the opening lyrics “I may not always love you” distinguishes this song from other love songs. Throughout the lyrics and music, there is a sense of ambiguity, with a really weak tonal centre (Scott, 2019). As David Bennett’s video shows, the music modulates multiple times, and there are many reversed chords, so the sound never feels stable.

I read various analyses of this song, and while I think the music harmony is beautifully composed, I’m going to concentrate on melody and counterpoint because these concepts are covered in this section of the course.

The opposing motion between the vocal melody and the bass is the first fascinating melodic design I recognized. As I explained below, there’s a lively conversation going on between the two voices, with one going down and the other going up, and vice – versa. Even when they appear to be heading in the same direction, as in bar 3 of this example, they quickly diverge in bar 4. I believe this was written with the goal of drawing attention to the ambiguity and leaving the listener in the dark about what to expect.

Another section that sparked my curiosity was the bridge or brake, in which the keyboards and flute play a short instrumental passage that repeats the preceding opposite motion, but in a much more pronounced manner.

This bridge introduces a three-voice counterpoint that I’ve always found fascinating. I did my best to transcribe as accurately as I could, so it’s not perfect, but it allowed me to understand how the three voices work together to form triads, and how they mostly move in thirds and sixth intervals.

The music comes to a close with a round that I discussed in a previous entry.

Overall, I believe I enjoy this song more now that I am fully aware of the incredible labour that went into the melody and the blending of all voices. I see some parallels with Bach’s work, but I think I need to learn more about Bach’s music to really see how they might be related.

References
